name: 1598_C. Delete Two Elements
description:
Monocarp has got an array a consisting of n integers. Let's denote k as the mathematic mean of these elements (note that it's possible that k is not an integer). 

The mathematic mean of an array of n elements is the sum of elements divided by the number of these elements (i. e. sum divided by n).

Monocarp wants to delete exactly two elements from a so that the mathematic mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still equal to k.

Your task is to calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.
repair_prompt:
Monocarp's array a consists of n integers. Let's denote k as the average value of these elements (note that k might not be an integer).

Monocarp wants to delete exactly two elements from a so that the mathematic mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still equal to k, which is the average of an array with n items, calculated as the total of those items divided by how many there are (i.e., sum divided by n).

Your task is to calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.

Monocarp wants to delete exactly two elements from array a so that the average value of the remaining elements is still equal to k, which may not be an integer due to the nature of the array's contents. Calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] where deleting the elements at these positions would maintain the average of the remaining elements equal to k, preserving the original array's overall average.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.

Monocarp's array a consists of n integers and the average value of these elements (k) may not be an integer. Monocarp wants to delete exactly two elements from a so that the mathematic mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still equal to k. Your task is to calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
completion:
t = int(input())

for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    k = total_sum / n
    pairs_count = 0
    
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i+1, n):
            sum_without_ij = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
            k_without_ij = sum_without_ij / (n - 2)
            
            if k_without_ij == k:
                pairs_count += 1
    
    print(pairs_count)

main()
completions:
# Read the number of testcases
t = int(input())

# Iterate over each testcase
for _ in range(t):
    # Read the number of elements in the array
    n = int(input())
    
    # Read the sequence of integers in the array
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    
    # Calculate the sum of the array
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    
    # Calculate the average value of the array
    k = total_sum / n
    
    # Initialize a counter for pairs of positions
    pairs_count = 0
    
    # Iterate over all pairs of positions [i, j]
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i+1, n):
            # Calculate the sum of elements excluding elements at positions i and j
            sum_without_ij = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
            
            # Calculate the average value of the remaining elements
            k_without_ij = sum_without_ij / (n - 2)
            
            # Check if the average value remains the same after deleting elements at positions i and j
            if k_without_ij == k:
                pairs_count += 1
    
    # Print the number of pairs of positions [i, j]
    print(pairs_count)

main()

t = int(input())

for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    count = 0
    
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i+1, n):
            current_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
            remaining_count = n - 2
            if current_sum / remaining_count == arr[i] + arr[j]:
                count += 1
    
    print(count)

t = int(input())

# Iterate over each testcase
for _ in range(t):
    # Read the number of elements in the array
    n = int(input())
    
    # Read the sequence of integers in the array
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    
    # Calculate the average value (k) of the array
    k = sum(arr) / n
    
    # Initialize a counter for pairs of positions
    pairs_count = 0
    
    # Iterate over all pairs of positions [i, j]
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i+1, n):
            # Calculate the sum of remaining elements after deleting elements at positions i and j
            remaining_sum = sum(arr) - arr[i] - arr[j]
            
            # Calculate the average of remaining elements
            remaining_avg = remaining_sum / (n - 2)
            
            # Check if the average of remaining elements is equal to k
            if remaining_avg == k:
                pairs_count += 1
    
    # Print the number of pairs of positions for each testcase
    print(pairs_count)

main()

Round_0.code:
# Read the number of testcases
t = int(input())

# Iterate over each testcase
for _ in range(t):
    # Read the number of elements in the array
    n = int(input())
    
    # Read the sequence of integers in the array
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    
    # Calculate the average value (k) of the array
    k = sum(arr) / n
    
    # Initialize a counter for pairs of positions
    pairs_count = 0
    
    # Iterate over all pairs of positions [i, j]
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i+1, n):
            # Calculate the sum of remaining elements after deleting elements at positions i and j
            remaining_sum = sum(arr) - arr[i] - arr[j]
            
            # Calculate the average of remaining elements
            remaining_avg = remaining_sum / (n - 2)
            
            # Check if the average of remaining elements is equal to k
            if remaining_avg == k:
                pairs_count += 1
    
    # Print the number of pairs of positions for each testcase
    print(pairs_count)

Round_0.code:
# Read the number of testcases
t = int(input())

# Iterate over each testcase
for _ in range(t):
    # Read the number of elements in the array
    n = int(input())
    
    # Read the sequence of integers in the array
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    
    # Calculate the sum of the array
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    
    # Calculate the average value of the array
    k = total_sum / n
    
    # Initialize a counter for pairs of positions
    pairs_count = 0
    
    # Iterate over all pairs of positions [i, j]
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i+1, n):
            # Calculate the sum of elements excluding elements at positions i and j
            sum_without_ij = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
            
            # Calculate the average value of the remaining elements
            k_without_ij = sum_without_ij / (n - 2)
            
            # Check if the average value remains the same after deleting elements at positions i and j
            if k_without_ij == k:
                pairs_count += 1
    
    # Print the number of pairs of positions [i, j]
    print(pairs_count)

for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    k = total_sum / n
    pairs_count = 0
    
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i+1, n):
            sum_without_ij = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
            k_without_ij = sum_without_ij / (n - 2)
            
            if k_without_ij == k:
                pairs_count += 1
    
    print(pairs_count)

prompt:
Monocarp's array a consists of n integers. Let's denote k as the average value of these elements (note that k might not be an integer).

Monocarp wants to delete exactly two elements from a so that the mathematic mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still equal to k, which is the average of an array with n items, calculated as the total of those items divided by how many there are (i.e., sum divided by n).

Your task is to calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

5

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.
